definition: to advise/to urge/to try to persuade/to exhort/to console/to soothe

sentences.english: But amid normal people these blandishments have no authority.
sentences.chinese: 不过这种甘言劝诱在普通人中影响力甚微。

sentences.english: The money, the ISSCR suggested, should not be enough to provide “undue inducement” for women to sell their eggs.
sentences.chinese: 这笔钱不应用于“过度劝诱”女性去卖自己的卵子。

sentences.english: It is propagandistic and manipulates the reader with purple prose.
sentences.chinese: 它用华丽的词藻堆砌起来的散文劝诱和操纵读者。

sentences.english: To induce by using strong personal attractiveness.
sentences.chinese: 用个人强烈的魅力哄诱，劝诱。

sentences.english: I think the essence of advertising is proselytizing.
sentences.chinese: 我认为广告的本质，就是劝诱。

sentences.english: Christianity, a strongly proselytizing religion, exists in all parts of the world.
sentences.chinese: 基督教，极力劝诱宗教，存在于世界所有地区。

sentences.english: The salesman induced her to buy the vacuum cleaner which she didn't really need.
sentences.chinese: 推销商劝诱她购买她并不需要的真空吸尘器。

sentences.english: The money, the ISSCR suggested, should not be enough to provide "undue inducement" for women to sell their eggs.
sentences.chinese: 这笔钱不应用于“过度劝诱”女性去卖自己的卵子。

sentences.english: It coaxes me to the vapor and the dusk.
sentences.chinese: 它劝诱我走向雾气朦胧的黄昏。

definition: to use gain as a lure
to coerce (sb into doing sth bad)/to lure (into a trap)/to seduce
to lobby/to campaign/to promote (an idea, a product)/(old) to visit various rulers and promote one's political ideas (in the Warring States period)
to entice/to lure/to scam/to hoodwink/to decoy
